Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:39PM phoenixsmom wrote: I think we're typing out of sync, lol.  Can I ask why you didn't have your small lump checked early on? And as far as I know, herceptin is wonderful for preventing her2 recurrence.  Having her2 cancer now is associated with much better prognosis than those who don't have it.

Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: phoenixsmom wrote: Hi everybody.  Because my tumors were large and bilateral, I had 5 months of ACT chemotherapy between April and September of this year,  and am still on Herceptin until next summer. I just had my bmx 21/2 weeks ago and dissection on my left arm. I have finally recieved the path report and the news is awesome but I am confused. This is the diagnosis: Right breast, simple mastectomy post-chemo -ductal carcinoma in situ, high nuclear grade (II/III), present in 3 of 29 blocks, largest focus 2mm -residual invasive carcinoma not identified Left breast, simple mastectomy post-chemo -small focus of atypical hyperplasia -residual invasive carcinoma not identified Left axillary nodes: 7 of 7 lymph nodes negative for malignancy Left apical node: fatty tissue, negative for malignancy (Note: I had SNB in right but dye didn't go anywhere so she examined during surgery) Okay, so what I am wondering is about the ductal carcinoma in situ.  Does this mean that these are new contained cancers that have appeared?  When I talked to the surgeon yesterday, she only had the phone report so I wasn't able to look at it until this morning when I saw my ps.  She told me I had a complete response, but what about this insitu stuff?  Its funny that the cancer was spread throughout my left breast and only in one small area in my right, and now it looks like the right is (was) more of a problem afterall.  Does anyone know how to explain this? (PS I am soooo thankful and grateful for such a good result, I just want to put my mind at ease). Dx 3/14/2009, ILC, 6cm+, Stage IIIA, 0/7 nodes, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 09:43PM phoenixsmom wrote: SherriG:  It makes me so nervous when people say I need rads.  My surgeon actually specializes in stage 3 cancer and she was confident with my decision.  If she had said that I needed it I would consider it....She told me only 10% of people have a complete response.  I feel very fortunate, but I also worked very hard with a naturopath, a homeopath, my oncologist and surgeon to choose the right treatment path for me.  Also, I have read many cases where women have chemo, surgery, and rads and still the cancer comes back.  I'm just working on strengthining my immune system right now and hoping my body will take care of the rest.  Also on herceptin for  quite a while more.  My question, is about that ductal carcinoma in situ that was on the path report.  I want to know if was there before, or if it showed up after my chemo.  I guess I'll have to wait ot speak to my onc to find out.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 17, 2009 07:17PM phoenixsmom wrote: Thank you Lexis.  I don't know much about the ductal carcinoma, because my initial dx was lobular invasive carcinoma.  I make a point of doing my homework as it pertains to the situation, so I am a bit ignorant in this area.  I don't think they mentioned anything about it being ductal in the beginning, I think it was the rest of it that was the main concern. Hi Unkle.  Thanx for the info.  I have been trying not to second guess myself after some comments that I should do radiation.  I trust myself to make the right decision.  I will be seeing my onc next week.  I can't wait to see the look on his face since I told him a long time ago I would be the one with a complete response.  I think he'll be very happy.  He has pushed me to do rads and also tamoxifen, but I told him only if I absolutely had to.  I'm only 10% pr+ and I'm er- and he wants me to take a drug that could cause a million other problems.  I like my oncologist because he's tough on people like me, but I take his advice, not his orders.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:28PM phoenixsmom wrote: I just don't understand why the radiation.  You did chemo.  You had your breast and probably the fascia removed. I see you're also on Herceptin? I know one thing is that if the cancer does come back in the chest area, they cannot reirradiate the same spot.  I also had both of my breasts removed, not just one.  I feel confident in my decision.  I have a 2 year old angel and I would go through radiation hell if I thought it would improve my odds in any way.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:48PM phoenixsmom wrote: Well, I wish you the best.  I still have to have my ovaries removed in the future, thanks to my wonderful genetic mutation.  I  just can't wait until this whole thing is a distant memory.  I feel too scared to be happy yet.  I just want to enjoy my son and my husband and get back to normal!  Have you had reconstruction?

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2009 09:32PM phoenixsmom wrote: Hi Kerry.  My oncologist is heading up a bunch of clinical trials, including one with Zometa.  I'm meeting again with him on the 26th to discuss my post surgery results.  I understand your opinion on the rads, but like I've said, it can only be done once.  Silly as it may sound, I like the idea of having options to fall back on should anything resurface in the future.  I do herceptin until next summer andI will continue on the anticancer supplements I have been taking since the beginning and plan to continue in the care of my naturopath as well, so hopefully that will be enough to catch the one or two cells that could possibly be kicking around somewhere.  Its been a really hard time for me, but I have tried to educate myself from many different pov's before making any decisions.  Right now I am happy with my choice.  If I had any positive nodes, I would have been open to other options, but thank God all were negative.  I had actually asked for sentinel biopsy but they told me there was 90%chance it was in the nodes.  You just never know.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 05:47PM phoenixsmom wrote: Are you having rads?  I'm not having any radiation.  I talked it over with my doc before surgery and after she said there's no reason to. I have tissue expanders in right now too, so I'm glad to be skipping that.  My main concern was the nodes, but I'm so relieved they all came up negative.  My tumors were invasive and lobular (the ones that shrank with chemo).  So these ductal ones, were they there before or these are new ones?  I have no breasts now so they're gone at least, I guess I should just be happy about that.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:21PM phoenixsmom wrote: I told my oncologist from day one that I would have a complete response and that I wouldn't do the radiation unless there was residual cancer or spread.  I am also a long time smoker and don't like the risks associated with radiation to the chest wall.  My surgeon specializes in stage III breast cancer and if she had suggested it was needed I would have taken it into consideration.  What did your path report say?
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:35PM phoenixsmom wrote: About the 6cm.  My oncologist told me 10cm, however, in later discussion with my surgeon, she said I had several large tumors clustered together (as per the MRI imaging), so their actual size was less than that (can't remember exactly) making a 10cm palpable mass. My oncologist told me my cancer was the size of a baseball the first time I met him, scared the living hell out of me.   Its amazing the difference in opinion and what you are told by different experts in the same field.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2009 06:37PM phoenixsmom wrote: Didn't you feel the herceptin might prevent that one cell from getting away?  I also see a naturopath and have been on a regimen of supplements and IV vitamin C from the getgo.  I guess we all choose different things.  My mother too has breast cancer.  She will be having surgery in about 2 weeks.  We both have the BRCA2 gene.  I hope her path report comes up as nice as mine.
Posts.Title: Just got path report, not sure about something phoenixsmom phoenixsmom

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 03:05PM phoenixsmom wrote: Hi Precious.  I had several large tumors, stage 3 and also had a complete response to chemo.  I asked for another MRI and was denied, as I too thought I could possibly escape further treatment.  I am soooo glad I had my mastectomy.  The path report showed no residual cancer, however, they found several small spots of ductal carcinoma in situ in the removed tissue.  I guess from what I've now learned, the chemo can't get rid of that.  So that cancer would still be there today.  The cancer cells throw out markers or seeds as my ND calls them, and could cause more cancer to pop up in the future.  You don't want to let your cancer throw out any more seeds that could end up growing anywhere else in your body.   From my experience so far, the surgery's not been too bad at all.  I'm 31 and I have to say things have come around much better than I had thought.  My best wishes for you.
Posts.Title: Neoadjudvant Chemo no surgery needed precioustime mumito
